Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A contested motion is scheduled soon, and the client relies on effective advocacy to preserve their position.
Story: I stared at my phone, the calendar app glaring back at me with two bolded dates—both tomorrow. My stepmother’s voice echoed in my mind, “It would mean so much if you led the ceremony this year. Your father would be proud.” I knew how important it was to her, to the family, to keep the tradition alive, especially after Dad passed. But as I scrolled through my emails, my client’s desperate message caught my eye: “I need you in court. This hearing could change everything for me.” The motion was complex, and I was the only one who knew the case inside out. My heart pounded as I imagined my stepmother’s disappointment if I didn’t show, and my client’s panic if I failed to appear. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, each demanding my presence, my loyalty, my best self. I closed my eyes, wishing I could split in two, but knowing I had to choose.
